sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: >humb; is an image viewer and browser written for the GNOME environment. It lets you browse your hard disk, showing you thumbnails of image files and view single images of many different formats.

The most common image formats are JPEG and GIF. The JPEG format is good for medium and big sized images because it has a high compression rate keeping a good image quality. The GIF format is used in Web pages for displaying little animations or little static images. Another important image format is PNG, this format is very common on Unix platforms and is considered a replacement of the GIF format which has license issues.
>humb; supports all this formats and many others, it also displays GIF animations.

>humb; not only lets you view image files but has many other features such as add comments to images, organize images in catalogs, print images, view slideshows, set your desktop background, and more.

sect1.title: Getting Started
sect1.para: This section provides information on how to start >humb;, and describes the main window interface.

sect2.title: To Start >humb;
sect2.para: You can start >humb; in the following ways:

listitem.para: Choose GraphicsgThumb.
Type gthumb, then press Return.

sect2.para: If you start >humb; from the command line you can specify the following options:

entry.para: View all the images with a .jpg extension.

sect2.title: When You Start >humb;
sect2.para:
When you start >humb; the following window is displayed:
The main window
The main window
The >humb; window contains the following elements:
Menubar
The menus on the menubar contain all of the commands that you can use >humb;
Toolbar
The toolbar contains a subset of the commands that you can access from the menubar.
Locationbar
The locationbar contains the current folder name.
Folder list
The folder list shows the sub-folders contained in the current folder.
Image list
The image list which shows the images in the current folder.
Statusbar
On the statusbar you can read:
the total number of images contained in the current folder and their total size.
the number of the selected images and their size.
some properties of the currently focused image.

sect1.title: Browsing Folders
sect1.para: Browser options can be found in the of the Preferences dialog.

sect2.title: To Change Folder
sect2.para:
If you want to change folder you have two ways:
click on the folder name in the folder list.
type the folder name in the location entry.
When using the location entry you can press CtrlTAB to try to automatically complete the folder name, this simplify the typing of long names. You can quickly give focus to the location entry pressing CtrlL.

To go to a previously visited folder you can use the toolbar Back button or click on the down arrow located near the button to display a menu that contains a list of the most recently visited folders. When this menu is displayed, if you keep the pointer on a folder name, you can read the full folder path in the statusbar.
The above commands are also present in the ViewGo menu.

sect2.title: To Sort Images
sect2.para: To sort images in a different order use the Sort images submenu in the View menu, use CtrlR to reload the current folder, type T to view or hide the thumbnails in the images list.

sect2.title: To Add a Folder to the Bookmarks
sect2.para: Frequently used folders can be added to the bookmark list for rapid access. Just go to the folder you want to add to the bookmarks and press CtrlD or use the command BookmarksAdd Bookmark. To remove or rearrange bookmarks in a different order use the BookmarksEdit Bookmarks command.

entry.para: Go to the previously visited folder.
Open selected files with an application

sect1.title: Working with Folders
sect1.para:
>humb; offers the all functionalities to manage folders.
WARNING
It's higly suggested to move and copy image folders with >humb;. This is because if you move or copy folders with >humb; image comments will remain attached to images as you expect, but if you move or copy folders with the file manager or other applications you will loose your comments.

sect2.title: To Create a Folder
sect2.para:
To create a new folder, perform the following steps:
Go to the folder where the new folder will be created.
Choose FileNew Folder to display the New Folder dialog.
Enter the new folder name.
Click on Create. >humb; creates a new folder.

sect2.title: To Open a Folder
sect2.para:
To open a folder with the file manager, perform the following steps:
Go to the folder you want to open.
Choose FileFolderOpen with the _File Manager. >humb; opens the folder with the file manager.

sect2.title: To Rename a Folder
sect2.para:
To rename a folder, perform the following steps:
Go to the folder you want to rename.
Choose FileFolderRename to display the Rename Folder dialog.
Enter the new folder name.
Click on Rename. >humb; renames the folder.

sect2.title: To Delete a Folder
sect2.para:
To delete a folder, perform the following steps:
Go to the folder you want to delete.
Choose FileFolderMove to Trash. >humb; moves the folder to the system trash.

sect2.title: To Copy a Folder
sect2.para:
To copy a folder to a different location, perform the following steps:
Go to the folder you want to copy.
Choose FileFolderCopy to display the Copy Folder dialog.
The Copy Folder dialog is used to choose the destination folder. You can type the folder name in the Folder entry, or click on Browse to select a folder from your disk. The Recents list contains the list of recently specified destination folders, while the Bookmarks list contains the folders you have a bookmark for. Click on a folder in these lists to insert the folder name in the Folder entry.
Click on Ok. >humb; copies the folder to the destination folder.

sect2.title: To Move a Folder
sect2.para:
To move a folder to a different location, perform the following steps:
Go to the folder you want to move.
Choose FileFolderMove to display the Move Folder dialog.
The Move Folder dialog is used to choose the destination folder. You can type the folder name in the Folder entry, or click on Browse to select a folder from your disk. The Recents list contains the list of recently specified destination folders, while the Bookmarks list contains the folders you have a bookmark for. Click on a folder in these lists to insert the folder name in the Folder entry.
Click on Ok. >humb; moves the folder to the destination folder.

sect1.title: Working with Images
sect1.para: This section shows how to view, modify and save images.

sect2.title: To View Images
sect2.para: In order to view an image just click on its thumbnail and the image will be visualized in the viewer pane. If the image doesn't fit the viewer pane you can give more space to the viewer hiding the browser, this can be accomplished double-clicking on the thumbnails or pressing the Return key, pressing it again the browser will be displayed again. Another way of viewing a big image is to view it in full screen mode, type V to activate/disactivate the full screen mode.
Mouse operations :

entry.para: Holding down the left button and moving the mouse

sect2.para:
Another way of moving images is by the navigation button :
located in the right bottom corner of the viewer window when the images does not fit in the window. Clicking and holding this button will show you a preview of the image. Moving the mouse you will move the image to the desired position.

sect2.title: To Modify Images
sect2.para: The current image can be modified in many ways. The commands used to modify an image are located in the Image menu.

entry.para: Create a mirror image by reflecting the image scanlines in the vertical direction.
Create a mirror image by reflecting the image scanlines in the horizontal direction (as in a mirror).
Change the image size performing a zoom in or out.
Change the image hue, lightness and saturation level.
Change the image brightness and contrast.
View the image in black and white.
Enhance the image equalizing its histogram.
Enhance the image adjusting color levels.

sect2.para:
When an image is modified the label "[modified]" is displayed near the image filename.
NOTE
Please note that this modifications do not change the image file. If you want to view the original image just click on its thumbnail again or use the FileRevert command.
You can save modified images, see to known how.

sect2.title: To Save Images
sect2.para:
To save an image, perform the following steps:
Display the image.
Modify the image (described in ). This step is optional.
Choose FileSave As.
Choose the filename and click on Ok.
>humb; displays the image format dialog from which you can choose specific file format options. Once you are ok with the options click on Ok. >humb; saves the image.

sect2.title: To Open Images with Another Program
sect2.para:
To open a series of images with another program, perform the following steps:
Go to the folder or catalog where the images are.
Select the images and choose FileOpen With to display the Open dialog.
Select an application from the Available applications list, or from the Recent applications list; or type a command in the Application entry.
Click on Open. >humb; opens the images.

sect2.title: To Rename Images
sect2.para:
To rename an image filename, perform the following steps:
Go to the folder or catalog where the image is.
Select the image and choose EditRename.
Enter the new filename and click on Rename. >humb; renames the image filename.

sect2.title: To Delete Images
sect2.para:
To delete a series of images, perform the following steps:
Go to the folder or catalog where the images are.
Select the images and choose EditMove to Trash. >humb; deletes the images moving them to the system trash.

sect2.title: To Copy Images
sect2.para:
To copy a series of images, perform the following steps:
Go to the folder or catalog where the images are.
Select the images and choose EditCopy to display the Choose the destination folder dialog.
Select a folder from the Recents list, or from the Bookmarks list; or type a folder name in the Folder entry.
Click on Ok. >humb; copies the images.

sect2.title: To Move Images
sect2.para:
To move a series of images, perform the following steps:
Go to the folder or catalog where the images are.
Select the images and choose EditMove to display the Choose the destination folder dialog.
Select a folder from the Recents list, or from the Bookmarks list; or type a folder name in the Folder entry.
Click on Ok. >humb; moves the images.

sect2.title: To Print Images
sect2.para:
To print an image, perform the following steps:
Go to the folder or catalog where the image is.
Select the image and choose FilePrint.
From the Print dialog you can
Choose the paper format and orientation from the Paper Details tag.
Choose the size of the image.
Move the image clicking on it with the left mouse button and dragging it.
Recenter the image on the page using the Center on Page button.
When you are ready to print click on Print. >humb; prints the image.

sect2.title: To Add a Comment
sect2.para: To add a comment to an image select the image and choose EditEdit comment or type C.

Comments are structured in various parts :
Comment: a free text describing the picture.
Place: the place the picture represents.
Date: the date the picture was taken.

Image comments are displayed in the image list in italic text above the image filename. If the comment is too long the simbol "[..]" is appended to the displayed part of the comment to signal you that the comment is not entirely visible, to view the whole comment use the image properties dialog that can be displayed using the FileProperties command or pressing I.

sect3.title: To Add a Comment to Many Images
sect3.para: To add a comment to many images, select the images and choose EditEdit comment or type C.
The Comment dialog will fill in the fields that have the same value for all the images leaving all other fields empty.
You can activate the Save only changed fields option (active by default) to change one or more fields of many comments leaving all other fields unchanged.

sect2.title: To Remove Comments
sect2.para:
To remove comments, perform the following steps:
Go to the folder or catalog where the images are.
Select the images and choose EditRemove comment. >humb; removes the comments.

sect1.title: Catalogs
sect1.para: Catalogs lets you organize images without moving them from a folder to another, think of them as "playlists" for images.

note.title: WARNING
note.para: Catalogs are not updated when you move images, if you want a more flexible catalog you can use the searches described in , searches are catalogs with search criteria attached, after moving images you can redo the search to get the catalog updated.

note.title: FOR EXPERTS
note.para: Catalogs are saved in the folder $(HOME)/.gnome2/gthumb/collections.

sect2.title: To View the List of Catalogs
sect2.para: Press Alt2 or select the ViewCatalogs command.

sect2.title: To View a Catalog
sect2.para: To view the content of a catalog just click on its name.
If you want to go to the image folder, select the image and use the ViewGoGo to the image folder command or press AltEnd.

sect2.title: To Add Images to a Catalog
sect2.para:
To add a series of images to a catalog, perform the following steps:
Select the images you want to add to the catalog and choose Edit Add to Catalog.
Select an existing catalog or create a new one.
Choose Ok. >humb; adds the selected images to the catalog.

sect2.title: To Delete Images from a Catalog
sect2.para: Select the images you want to delete then use the Edit Delete from Catalog command.

sect2.title: To Rename, Delete or Move Catalogs
sect2.para: Select the catalog and use the corrisponding command in the File menu, or use the context menu pressing the right mouse button on the name of the catalog in the catalog list.

sect1.title: To Find Images
sect1.para: To find images on your hard disk choose EditFind.

From the Find dialog you can specify a file name or a pattern in the File name entry, for example :
foo.jpg: >humb; searches for files named foo.jpg
*.png: >humb; searches for files with the png extension.
*.gif; *.jpg: >humb; searches for files with the gif or jpg extension. with an image editor

Other search rules:
Start at: The folder where the search will start from.
Include sub-folder: Whether to search even in the sub folders.
Comment: A list of phrases the comment of the image must contain, for example:
paolo: will search for images that have "paolo" in the comment.
my birthday: will search for images that have "my birthday" in the comment.
holiday ; rome: will search for images that have "holiday" OR "rome" in the comment.
holiday in rome ; my birthday: will search for images that have "holiday in rome" OR "my birthday" in the comment.
Place: A list of phrases the place field of the comment must contain, for example:
rome: will search for images that have "rome" in the place field.
paris ; rome ; london: will search for images that have "paris" OR "rome" OR "london" in the place field.
Date: The criteria the date field of the comment must respect:
any: the date field is ignored.
before, equal to, after: the date must be less recent, equal to or more recent than the date specified.
Categories: The list of categories an images must belong to. Categories can be added to images using the EditCategories command or pressing K. Examples:
family: images must have "family" has one of their keywords.
me, family: images must have "family" and/or "me" in the keywords list.
You can choose to search for images that belongs to all the specified categories or at least to one of them, checking the corresponding option.
If you use more than one criteria images must respect all of them.
The search is always case insensitive.

Click on Search to start the search. Once the search has finished you will see the list of images that matches your search, if you want to see these images click on View, if you want to make another search click onNew Search.

If you choose to view the images, a catalog named Search Results will be created and visualized automatically. A catalog created in this way has a special icon, a magnifier, this is because on this type of catalogs you can perform two more operations: Edit Search and Redo Search .
The "Search Result" catalog
The "Search Result" catalog
These operations can be selected from the File Search menu, or from the menu that pops up when pressing the right mouse button on the catalog name.
The Edit Search command lets you re-edit the search rules, while Redo Search lets you restart the search, at the end of the search you can decide whether to save the result in the catalog or not.

sect1.title: Slide Shows
sect1.para: You can start a slide show of the images in the current folder by pressing S or selecting the View Slide Show menu item. To stop the slide show press S again.

Switching on/off the full screen mode does not stop the slide show. If the Switch to full screen option is on then the slide show is started in fullscreen mode and exiting from the fullscreen mode stops the slide show.
The slide show is interrupted when you change folder or re-load the current one.
With the slideshow tool and the fullscreen mode you can do presetations. There are two types of presentations: automatic presentations and manual presentations.

sect2.title: How To Do an Automatic Presentation
sect2.para: To do an automatic presentation, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Go to the folder or catalog containing the images you want to present.
Choose ViewSlide Show or press S. >humb; starts an automatic presentation of the images catained in the folder or catalog.

sect2.para: To stop the presentation press S or Q or Esc.
The slide show behaviour can be personalized from the Preferences dialog in the

sect2.title: How To Do a Manual Presentation
sect2.para: To do a manual presentation, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Go to the folder or catalog containing the images you want to present.
Select the image from which you want to start the presentation.
Press V. >humb; displays the image in fullscreen mode.
Press Space or N. >humb; displays the next image.
Press BackSpace or B. >humb; displays the previuos image.

sect2.para: To stop the presentation press Q or Esc.

sect2.title: To Set the Desktop Wallpaper
sect2.para:
If you want to set the selected image as desktop wallpaper select the menu Set Image as Wallpaper from the Tools menu. The menu contains four items each of which let you set the wallpaper in a different way:
Centered -- The image will be centered on the screen.
Tiled -- The image will be duplicated on the screen as tiles on the floor.
Stretched -- The image will be scaled to fill the screen changing proportions if needed.
Scaled -- The image will be scaled to fill the screen mantaining the aspect ratio.

If you want to restore the old wallpaper use the
Tools Set Image as Wallpaper Restore item.

sect2.title: To Rotate JPEG Images Without Loss of Quality
sect2.para: Usually if you want to rotate an image you have to open the image with an editor, rotate the image and save it. This works good for image formats such as PNG or GIF, but results in a loss of quality for JPEG images.
If you want to rotate JPEG images without losing image quality, select the images you want to rotate and use the ToolsRotate JPEG command.

If you check the Apply to all images option the rotation is applied to the currently displayed image as well as to all the remaining images you have selected, otherwise, once the rotation has been performed on the current image, the next image in the selection is displayed, and you can choose another type of rotation.
If the selection contains some non-JPEG images, they are simply ignored.

sect2.title: To Convert Images Format
sect2.para: With this tool you can change the format of images. To use it select the images you want to convert, and use the ToolsConvert Format command.

The Convert Format dialog offers you the following options:
Image type: this is the format you want to convert images into.
Overwrite mode: a converted image has the same name of the original image except for the extension which is determined by the new format, an image with the new name can already exist in the destination folder, this option lets you decide what to do when such a case occurs. If use choose skip the new image won't be created; rename will ask you to specify a new name; ask will ask you whether to overwrite the old image or not and overwrite will overwrite the old image without asking.
Remove original: lets you remove the original image. If an image is not converted because of an error it will not be removed.

sect2.title: To Rename a Series of Images
sect2.para: With this tool you can change a series of image filenames specifing a name template. In order to use it select the images you want to rename, and select the ToolsRename Series command.

The name template is simply a name that must be used for all of the images, furthermore you can use two special characters to make the new names different each other:
# -- This symbol will be replaced with the value of a counter that increments itself by 1 passing from one image to another. If you specify this symbols in sequence you'll get leading zeros if the counter value has a lesser number of digits, for example ### will produce the sequence: 001, 002, 003, etc..
* -- This symbol will be replaced with the image original name.
The list at the bottom of the dialog display how the filenames will be renamed.

If the renaming of an image can overwrite an already existing image you will be asked how to proceed, five options are available: overwrite the image, do not overwrite the image, always overwrite, never overwrite, specify a new name.

sect2.title: To Change Images Date
sect2.para: If you want to change the last modified date of a series of images, select the images and use the ToolsChange Date command.

sect2.title: To Create an Index Image
sect2.para: An index image is an image that contains small previews of a series of images. If you want to create an index image select the images you want to insert in the index and then use the ToolsCreate Index Image command.

sect1.title: Maintenance
sect1.para: To get access to maintenance operations select the ToolsMaintenance menu item.

Backup Comments -- With this command you can create an archive of all the comments you have writed. After pressing the button you have to enter the archive name, for example: comments.tgz, or comments.zip. The archive is created using the application File Roller.

Restore Comments From a Backup File -- Use this command if you want to restore comments previously saved in an archive. After pressing the button you have to specify the archive where the comments are stored. The archive is extracted using the application File Roller.

Delete Old Comments -- If you use >humb; to delete or move images, comments are deleted and moved accordingly. Other applications do not handle image comments so it can happen that a comment exists but the relative image does not exist anymore. This command lets you delete such comments.
Delete ALL Comments -- This command will delete all the comments you have written.

Thumbnails are small versions of the images you have on your disk, they are used to speed up browsing. Thumbnails can use a lot of space, so in order to save disk space you may wish to delete all the thumbnails or only the thumbnails of no more existing images. The commands in the Thumbnails section let you do this.

sect1.title: Preferences
sect1.para: To configure >humb;, open Preferences dialog by selecting EditPreferences .
This dialog contains four tabs described in detail below. At the bottom of the dialog window, you'll find the following buttons:

listitem.para: Help: shows this manual.
Close: closes the dialog.

sect1.para: Keep in mind that when you change an option it will automatically applied, this is why there is no Ok or Apply button.

sect2.title: General Tab
sect2.para: This tab allows you to set the following options:

listitem.para: Select the layout of >humb; main window, i.e. the positions of directory list window, the image (thumbnail) list window, and the main image viewer window.
The toolbar style
Directory to show on startup
The history length, that is the maximal number of locations to show in Go menu. The default is 15.

sect2.title: Browser Tab
sect2.para: In this tab, you can configure the following options:

listitem.para: This option (which you can activate simply pressing T) controls whether >humb; should show thumbnails.
This option controls whether >humb; should show comments (including date and place) in the image list. By default, >humb; shows the comment as a caption under the thumbnail.

This option controls whether >humb; should show files with the names starting with dot (.). These files usually contain system information or applications settings. Since these files almost never contain user data, by default they are not shown by file manager and other applications. In most cases, you should leave this option unselected.

Here you can select the thumbnails size to your taste. By default, >humb; display thumbnails of size 95x95 pixels. If you like to view as much thumbnails as possible select a small thumbnail size, if you want to view detailed thumbnails select a big size. The other option lets you decide whether to save the thumbnails or not, saving thumbnails is highly recommended because this let you speed up browsing of folders you already visited, the drawback is that thumbnails occupy disk space so if your free space is limited you may prefer to disable this option but in most cases you should leave this option selected.

Here you can choose whether to change folder by doing a single or a double click on the folder name. The single click can be usefull if you are used to quickly browse your hard disk searching for images. The default behaviour is to follow the Nautilus file manager policy. Furthermore you can select whether >humb; should ask for confirmation before deleting an image or a catalog, and whether >humb; should determine image type by looking at the file extension or by looking at the file content. Determining file type from the content is more reliable (some applications may create files with extension not matching the actual file type) but slower. If you have a fast system, select Determine image type from content.

sect2.title: Viewer Tab
sect2.para: This tab contains options for viewer window:

listitem.para: This controls the method used for showing rescaled image. Possible choices are high quality (slow on old machines or when viewing big images) and low quality (always fast).
Controls initial zoom level to use for an image.
Controls the background used for partly transparent images. By default the transparent part of the image is replaced the window background color,that is the none option.
This option only has effect for partly transparent images and only if checked transparency type was selected. It controls the size and colors of checker board pattern used for the background.

sect2.title: Slide Show Tab
sect2.para: This tab contains the options controlling slide show mode (which you can start by selecting Tools Slide Show or by using CtrlS shortcut). The options include direction (forward/backwards), and delay between images. You can also specify whether the slide show should wrap around (i.e., after showing the last image start again form the beginning) and automatically switch to fullscreen mode.
